question.title: HttpMediaTypeNotSupportedException - Content-Type 'application/json;charset=UTF-8' is not supported
question.body:
I'm working on a Spring Boot application with a @PatchMapping method that consumes application/json. However, when I send a PATCH request, I get the following exception:

org.springframework.web.HttpMediaTypeNotSupportedException: Content-Type 'application/json;charset=UTF-8' is not supported`

Here’s the @PatchMapping method in my controller:

@PatchMapping(value = "", consumes = {MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON_VALUE})
@Tag(name = "User", description = "Update the authenticated user with given information.")
@ApiResponse(responseCode = "200", description = "Ok", content = {@Content(mediaType = "application/json", schema = @Schema(implementation = UserDTO.class))})
@HasAnyRole
public ResponseEntity<UserDTO> update(@RequestBody UpdateUserDTO updateUserDto) {
    User user = authService.getCurrentUser();

    var updateUserVo = mapUser.toUpdateUserVo(updateUserDto);
    var updatedUser = userService.update(user.getId(), updateUserVo);
    var updatedUserDto = mapUser.toUserDto(updatedUser);

    return new ResponseEntity<>(updatedUserDto, HttpStatus.OK);
}

My User class contains fields like emailAddress, firstName, lastName, and a Map<Language, LanguageLevel> languages.

When sending the request, the Content-Type header includes application/json;charset=UTF-8, and I’m wondering, why this is causing the error. How can I resolve this issue? Should I modify the @PatchMapping to allow charset=UTF-8, or is there another solution?

Additionally, here’s the structure of the User class:

@Builder
@Getter
@Setter
@ToString
@EqualsAndHashCode
public class User {
    private Long id;
    private String emailAddress;
    private String firstName;
    private String lastName;
    private String street;
    private String houseNumber;
    private String postalCode;
    private String city;
    private String phoneNumber;
    private LocalDate careerStartDate;
    @Builder.Default
    private Map<Language, LanguageLevel> languages = new HashMap<>();
}

I tried it with a Postman test to find out what was wrong, but it didn't work.

answers.body:
the issue is that Spring treats the consumes values literally. You are only allowing application/json and therefore the value application/json;charset=UTF-8 doesn't get allowed.

Expand the allowed values like so:

@PatchMapping(consumes = {"application/json", "application/json;charset=UTF-8"})

or just remove the limitation to allow all charsets:

@PatchMapping
